awd_titl_txt: REU Site:  Research Training in Place-Based Field Research
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to the Rocky Mountain Biological Laboratory located in Gothic, CO, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2018-2022.   Resesarch is conducted throughout the Gunnison Basin. The theme of the program is the Ecology of Place, or using a deep understanding of a place to generate general scientific insights.  Students design and implement a field research program and present results orally and in writing at the end of the summer.  Students also participate in professional development opportunities throughout the summer, such as discussions of scientific and non-academic careers, as well as responsible conduct of research topics such as sexual harassment and the ethics of research. The program recruit students nationally, building on established collaborative relationships with the Los Angeles community colleges.  Students apply online, and submit essays and letters of reference. Students for whom the program will have a large impact, including students who would be unable to participate in summer research without financial support, are encouraged to apply.

It is anticipated that a total of 50 students primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program over five years.  The goal is that 70% of the participants will be minority students and at least 35% of the students will have a community college background. Students will learn how research is conducted, many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences. Approximately one-third of the students will publish results in scientific journals.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system as well as RMBL surveys. More information about the program is available by visiting rmbl.org/education , or by contacting the PI (Dr. Ian Billick, director@rmbl.org) or the co-PI (Dr. Jennifer Reithel at sd@rmbl.org).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Rocky Mountain Biological Laboratory (RMBL) hosted 70 undergraduates from 2018-2022 in its REU undergraduate research program. Funding for these students was provided by the National Science Foundation through its Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program. Fifty students were part of the core site program. An additional 20 students were funded by supplements during Covid. The goals of this program were to diversify the scientific workforce by hosting a significant number of students from minority groups underrepresented in the sciences and to provide research training to students from community colleges. An admissions’ focus on students from community colleges, as well as on other participants with limited research opportunities, generated a diverse pool of participants. Our program successfully reaches students from community colleges, especially Hispanic-serving institutions in the Los Angeles area. We have hosted students from San Bernadino Valley, Santa Ana, Chaffey, Crafton Hills, Santa Barbara, Rio Hondo, Citrus, East LA, and Pasadena. Of the core 50 students, half were from community colleges, approximately half were first generation college students and more than 80% were members of under-represented minority groups.

Unlike many REU sites, we successfully offered undergraduate research opportunities during Covid. To help fill the country's need for student research opportunities, we received NSF supplementary funds to support an additional 10 REU students in each of 2020 and 2021, bringing the total number of REU students to 70 over the entirety of this grant.  Besides the REU students, NSF supplemental funding supported 8 returning REU students from community colleges. We have found that for less experienced students, a second summer at RMBL goes a long way towards students self-identifying as scientists. NSF supplemental funding also supported research experiences for two female Hispanic post-baccalaureate students (REPS supplement award), 2 high school students (RAHSS supplement award), and 4 professors from teaching schools bringing research back to their classrooms (ROA supplement award).

All undergraduate student participants conducted independent research projects under the supervision of a scientist. Students developed research proposals, mapped their research sites, collected and analyzed data, archived their data along with metadata, and presented results in both written and oral form. Additionally, students participated in a range of enrichment activities, including responsible conduct of research sessions, skills workshops, seminar series and discussion sessions.

In terms of research outcomes, twenty-eight undergraduate student participants were co-authors on 21 peer-reviewed scientific publications, eight gave talks or presented posters at professional meetings based upon their research and three students received travel awards to present at meetings.

Long-term tracking dating back to the program's start indicates that a large number of student participants go on to a career in the sciences. Operating since 1991, approximately half the students pursue graduate training. At least 45 alumni, 19 of whom are , have gone on to obtain faculty positions at academic institutions. Additionally, our longitudinal tracking indicates many alumni, including many under-represented participants, go on to non-academic, science-based careers, including a high school science teacher, environmental consultant, county parks naturalist, technician testing biopharmaceuticals, biological technician surveying frogs, museum math and science program coordinator, ecosystem regeneration technician, herbarium coordinator, and naturalist / environmental educators. Interestingly, 93% of respondents to a longitudinal survey indicated that science is important to their current job, with 80% of respondents currently considering themselves a scientist, and 85% indicating they are more likely to consider themselves a scientist because of their time at the Rocky Mountain Biological Laboratory.
